Celina is a member of the Idunda borrower group in Kihesa,Iringa,she is 36 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 4 children.Her children are aged 15,9,17.2 years.she also cares for other 2 dependents.

Celina started her own business selling tomatoes,potatoes,anions 12years ago,she works 9 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Celina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more tomatoes,anion,potatoes.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Celina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes,anions

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 56-year-old widow who lives in the same house with her daughter, her daughter’s husband and their children. Nada works as a babysitter at home and can earn round 200 KM monthly. This is the only income she has and it is enough for her basic needs.

Nada has worked for a many years as a tailor in a big factory but that factory is closed now. Nada has one old sewing machine and, from time to time, she uses it to fix some clothes.

Nada has a long experience in tailoring and she has decided to buy a new sewing machine and needs a loan to purchase it. That is the reason Nada has requested her first loan from WWI (Žene za Žene International) in amount of 600 KM. She hopes to increase her income and provide a more comfortable life for herself.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Csac Group

texts.en:
These are board members of Comfort, Support and Care (CSAC), a community- based organization. These board members came to SMT/Kiva to seek a loan of Le 7,000,000 after several unsuccessful attempts from other NGOs within and outside of Makeni town. They have planted a rice farm of 120 acres of land in a village called Rulakoh, about seven miles from Makeni, but are currently in need of labor to help them in the weeding, bird scareing and harvesting. Thus with the Le 7,000,000.00, they will be able to achieve this. 

CSAC is a community based organization registered in 2004 to help ensure the well being of the disabled and their children in the Bombali district. The organization has a membership of 1000 disabled drawn from four different categories of the disabled: leprosy victims, polio victims, amputees and the blind. CSAC carries out agricultural activities and provides free schooling for the children of the disabled.

Alimany Edward K. is the founder of this organization. He has lived in New York for over twenty-four years but had never seen the disabled begging for a living. But back home in Sierra Leone, the disabled, together with their children, go out begging for a living. This was appalling to Alimany, especially so for the children who were not handicapped. Without any form of empowerment for these children, their plight will be miserable in the future once their parents have passed away – begging will no longer help them since they are not in any way handicapped. Thus Alimany K. decided to form this organization to help the handicapped by engaging them in agriculture and setting up of a school for their children. 

So far, CSAC has been able to give education to over 200 children of the disabled. They also give medical and feeding assistance to the most vulnerable of the disabled. However, their two main challenges are 1) labor vacuum – because of their disabilities, they can not work efficiently on the farm and 2) inadequate funds to ensure proper implementation of their programs. However, with this loan, SMT/Kiva will salvage the issue of labor vacuum.

James S. K. (left), a non-disabled himself, is currently acting as Director of the Organization. He was born in Makeni forty-nine years ago. He is married with two children.

loans.use: Pay labor for weeding, bird scareing and harvesting

 Nicolina started her own food business selling bites(maandazi) 16 years ago,she works 13 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tanzania shillings.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Nicolina hopes to save money,pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.name: Jelica

texts.en:
Jelica was born in 1954. She is unemployed at the moment and lives with her sons. She worked in a textile factory as a tailor for a long time. Now, she is a housewife and makes some earnings by fixing old clothes for some secondhand stores. She cannot earn much but her sons are helping her.

Jelica is a member of our society – Women for Women International – and now she has requested a loan of 900 KM from WWI. She will use this loan to buy a new sewing machine and some materials to make clothes. Thanks to her long experience, she thinks that she will make a success in this business and become independent of her sons.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en:
K. Pascal is thirty-three years old and a permanent residence of Kyotera town. He is the head teacher of a local school in Kyotera known as Infant primary school Kyotera. He resides in Kinankole Mutokula Local Council zone. He is a married man blessed with one child.

He is running a grocery shop near Kyotera which he started in the year 2006, so he is three years in his business so far. He is using the loan for the sole purpose of buying more items such as sugar, salt, soft drinks, biscuits, glucose, eggs, etc. for his retail grocery shop, mostly items healthy for pupils. His future hopes and plans are to expand his retail grocery shop so that it can serve the whole school and always to try very much to give the best to his pupils.

loans.use: For buying items such as sugar, salt, soft drinks, biscuits, glucose, eggs, etc. for his retail grocery shop.

loans.name: Hasifah

texts.en:
N. Hasifah is the owner of Musawos' grocery shop located along Old Masaka Road opposite Kalisizo Main Hospital. She is a business lady, age 32, married with one child. Her shop sells different types of drinks like passion juice, Splash, Ribena, Lucozade and various other items. She is using this loan to purchase more drinks in order to meet the high demands of her customers, who are mostly patients from Kalisizo Hospital.

Her hope for the future is to expand her business, accumulate profits and then be able to put up a permanent house in Kalisizo town and give her children a brighter future.

loans.name: Henry Lusinga

texts.en:
Henry O. is 42 years old, married to Josephine Khalechi who is a shopkeeper and they have four children. His business is located within Eldoret Town and his major customers are residents of Eldoret Town. He has been in the handcart transportation business for the past twelve years now. 

Henry was introduced to KADET by an existing member. He wants to service a loan with which he intends to buy another trolley and one more handcart for his business. 

In the future, he dreams of buying a pick-up and dairy cattle.

loans.name: Chérubins Plus Group

texts.fr:
Chérubins Plus est un groupe composé de 33 membres dont Modeste M. est président. Ce groupe a déjà reçu les prêts de Kiva qu’il a remboursé correctement.
Modeste a comme activités commerciales, la fabrication artisanale des savons qu’il vend ainsi qu’une cabine téléphonique. Ses affaires se localisent dans le quartier périphérique le plus peuplé de Kinshasa, situé au nord de la ville. Pour réaliser son ambition d’ouvrir une usine de fabrication des savons à fournir aux détaillants, Modeste travaille durement en réinvestissant ses bénéfices accumulés. Il compte aussi sur les prêts de Kiva à travers Hope. Il en a déjà reçu trois qu’il remboursé totalement. Le prochain crédit lui servira d’acheter des produits de fabrication des savons à revendre en vue d’accroitre le bénéfice. Actuellement, ses activités lui génèrent un bénéfice de $45 par semaine. Modeste est âgé de 54 ans, marié et père de 6 enfants âgés entre 12 et 30 ans. Tous vont à l’école.
texts.en:
Chérubins Plus is a group composed of 33 members, and its president is Mr. Modeste M.. This group has already received Kiva loans that it repaid correctly. Modeste has a commercial business making artisanal soaps, which he sells. He has a telephone booth as well. His businesses are located in the most populated outlying district of Kinshasa and north of the city. To realize his ambition of opening a factory for making soaps to provide to retailers, Modeste works hard while reinvesting his accumulated profits. Also, he is counting on Kiva loans through the micro-finance institution Hope RDC. He has already received three of them, which he totally repaid. The next loan will be used to buy goods for making soaps to sell, with the aim of growing his profits. Currently, his businesses generate a profit of $45 a week for him. Modeste is 54 years old, married, and the father of six children, ages 12 to 30. All of them go to school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy goods for making soaps to sell

Greetings from M. Angeline,

Angeline is a widow who is 43 years old and takes care of two children with the following years old: 16, and 19. Angeline has been selling charcoal for the past five years and She earns a monthly profit of 80,000 RWF by working from 6:00 AM to 8:00 PM.

Angeline is requesting her first loan of 500,000 RWF From Vision Finance Company s.a

With this requested loan, Angeline hopes to expand her business through purchasing more charcoal for sales.

Through accessing this new loan, believes to get more food for her family and paying school fees to her children.

loans.name: Corazon Chopcca Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Corazon D. Chopcca, pertenece al distrito D. Yauli, provincia D. Huancavelica ubicada en el departamento D. Huancavelica. L. comunidad se encuentra rodeada D. cerros, con bellos paisajes con árboles y hierbas silvestres, el paisaje llamado Nación Chopcca muestra a las señoras con vestidos coloridos tejidos a mano, su actividada principal es L. artesanía, L. agricultura y un poco D. ganadería.

Margarita es casada y tiene 04 hijos. Margarita teje desD. muy niña, habilidad que le genera algún ingreso, ya que envía sus tejidos para su venta a L. capital, cada vez que algún conocido viaja a elL.. Margarita, necesita un préstamo D. S/200.00 para comprar materia prima para continuar con sus tejidos. A elL. le gustaría tener sus propias maquina D. tejer.

Aurelia es casada y tiene 06 hijos. Aurelia scomo L. mayoria D. las mujeres D. su comunidad tambien se dedica al tejido, pero tambien tiene una pequeña bodega, que poco a poco va creciendo, gracias a L. inversión que esta haciendo en elL.. Aurelia solicita un prestamo D. S/200.00 para abastecer su tienda, con productos que demandan mayor salida. 

Juana es casada y tiene 03 hijos. Juana venD. comida en las ferias y L. vez se dedica a tejer pequeñas prendas, las cuales envía a Lima para su venta.  Juan requiere D. un préstamo D. S/200 soles para comprara utensilios, mesas y bancas para su negocio.
texts.en:
The Corazon D. Chopcca Community Banks belongs to the Yauli district in the Huancavelica province, which is located in the Huancavelica department. The community is surrounded by hills and pretty scenery of trees and wild grasses. The Nación Chopcca landscape shows women dressed in colorful hand woven clothing. Their primary activity is handicrafts, agriculture, and a little livestock. Margarita is married and has four children. Margarita has been weaving since she was a very little girl. This ability generates some income. She sends her weavings to be sold in the capital every time that someone she knows goes there. Margarita needs a loan for 200 PEN to buy raw material to continue with her weavings. She would like to have her own weaving machine. Aurelia is married and has six children. Aurelia, like most of the women in the community, also weaves. But, she also has a small grocery store. Little by little, the store is growing thanks to the investment she is making in it. Aurelia needs a loan for 200 PEN to stock her store with products that are in greater demand. Juana is married and has 3 children. Juana sells food in the fairs. She also weaves small articles of clothing, which she sends to Lima to sell. Juana needs a loan for 200 PEN to buy utensils, tables, and benches for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The 15 member of the Community Bank are asking for 4,000 PEN to invest in their handicrafts businesses

Greetings from Kigali,Rwanda! 

M. Violette is 37 years old, she is married, and she has four children with the ages 16,14,10 and 8 years old. 

She has 10 years of experience in selling various drinks as found on the icluded picture.Her monthly profit is 250,000. Now she needs her first loan of 500,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company.

With this requested loan, Violette hopes to expand her business through purchasing more drinks in order to get more profit than before.

Once that purpose is achieved, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children for good schools and also to save for the future.

loans.use: water,juice,and cold drinks

loans.name: La Alternativa 1,4 Group

texts.en:
Juana E. runs a clothing business from her home near Samaná, Dominican Republic. For the past six years, she has been dedicated to providing her neighbors with men’s, women’s and children’s apparel, and has found her business to be quite successful. She took out her first microloan a year and a half ago, and is beginning her fourth loan cycle with Esperanza.

A smart businesswoman, Juana seeks out the best prices for clothing from cities all across the northwestern part of the Dominican Republic – she even travels to the border with Haiti to buy less expensive clothing in order to help garner a profit. She is so well known in her neighborhood that she no longer has to go door to door to sell clothing. Before she goes to Santiago or another location to purchase her inventory, individuals come to her home and request a customized list, and Juana is more than happy to find exactly what they want.

Currently living with just her husband, Juana has seen all three of her children (two daughters and one son), not only get married, but also pursue college education. With her business, Juana has been able to support her children’s education. One wishes to be a nurse and another studies English. Smiling, she adds (as any mom with college-age students might say), “Now they have to pay the university on their own! When you’re married, you pay for your own stuff.”

In the future, Juana wishes to have her own store where she can sell her clothing. She is hoping that future earnings can help her afford to build an extra room on her house dedicated solely to her business. To improve her home, she is also hoping that extra profits might allow her to replace her wood walls with ones made of concrete blocks.

Thank you for your loan to Juana and the others in her group!

loans.use: To buy new men's, women's and children's clothing

loans.name: Aristide

texts.en:
Greetings from U. Aristide,

Aristide is 27 years old and is single. He has been in the business of shopping for the past 5 years and the monthly profit is 100,000 RWF.

He is requesting his first loan of 500,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company s.a
With this requested loan,Aristide hopes to expand his business through purchasing more goods.

Through accessing this new loan, Aristide has hope for the future by attending university and saving some money.

loans.use: expand his business

loans.name: Lesther Vidal

texts.es: El joven Lesther Vidal 23 años de edad, soltero, habita en Villa del Carmen del departamento Managua, tiene un hijo de dos años, sus metas es mejorar el nivel de vida para beneficio de su familia, trabaja en la Alcaldía de Villa del Carmen, anteriormente trabajaba en una panadería, ha encontrado como dificulta que el salario no alcanza para realiza mejoras en su vivienda. Con el préstamo en Afodenic comprara materiales de construcción como: cemento, hierro, bloques, piso y otros. Ya que la infraestructura de su casa esta desgastadas y requiere de retoques, que le ofrecerá protección y seguridad a su familia.
texts.en:
Lesther Vidal is 23 years old,single, and lives in Villa del Carmen, located in the department of Managua. He has a 2 year old son. His goal is to improve his quality of life to benefit his family. He now works in the Villa del Carmen mayor’s office. Before, he worked in a bakery. He has found it difficult because his salary is not sufficient to make improvements for his house. With the Afodenic loan, he will purchase construction materials such as cement, iron, blocks, flooring, and others. The infrastructure in his house is worn out and requires retouching, which will offer protection and security for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to make home improvements

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For making and selling food

loans.name: Raúl

texts.es:
Raúl T. C. es un señor de 44 años de edad, vecino de  una comunidad  rural de Costa Rica situada 45 kilómetros al sur de San José llamada San Cristóbal Norte. San Cristóbal es una zona un poco montañosa donde se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, agricultura de hortalizas, café y otros, artesanía, ganadería y muchas otras actividades. Don Raúl  vive con su esposa y con sus tres hijos. 

Desde hace 12 años que don Raúl inició un negocio de confección de ropa, mayormente confeccionando uniformes deportivos. El elabora diferentes tipos de prendas de vestir que luego vende en su negocio. Su microempresa ha ayudado a que la condición de vida de su familia haya mejorado considerablemente. Dice que el poder brindar un buen servicio a las personas y cumplir con sus exigencias, son la base del éxito del negocio.

Actualmente don Raúl requiere un préstamo de ¢685.000 (seiscientos ochenta y cinco mil colones) para comprar una máquina especial para realizar impresiones digitales en telas. Con esta inversión espera poder incrementar su producción y mejorar la calidad de los  productos. Afirma que gracias a este préstamo podrá atraer a más clientes, ofrecer mejores alternativas y mejorar considerablemente la calidad de sus productos.

Don Raúl es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal San Cristóbal Norte (SACRIN), una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Ha recibido 4 microcréditos y los ha cancelado responsablemente.
texts.en:
Raúl T. C. is a 44 year old man. He is a neighbor of a rural Costa Rican community called San Cristóbal Norte, located 45 kilometers south of San José. San Cristóbal is a slightly mountainous zone where they engage in business activities such as storekeeping, vegetable agriculture, coffee, handicrafts, cattle farming, and many others. Raúl lives with his wife and three children.

Raúl started a clothing production business 12 years ago, mainly producing sport uniforms. He makes different types of clothing that he then sells in his business. His small business has helped his family’s quality of life to improve considerably. He says that the ability to provide good services to people and meet their demands is the base to the business’ success.

Raúl currently needs a loan of 685.000 CRC to purchase a special machine to create digital impressions on the fabric. With this investment, he hopes to be able to increase his production and improve the quality of his products. He states that thanks to this loan, he will be able to attract more clients, offer better alternatives, and considerably improve the quality of his products.

Raúl is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal San Cristóbal Norte (SACRIN), one of EDESA’s 100 partner organizations in Costa Rica. He has received 4 microloans and he has repaid them all responsibly.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a machine to make digital impressions on fabric

loans.name: Aldo Jose

texts.es: El señor Aldo O., habitante de Villa del Carmen, su acompañante trabajadora de una empresa privada, tiene un hijo de siete años de edad, es un hombre luchador, buscando lo mejor para su familia, buen padre e hijo. Dentro de sus planes realizarle mejoras a su vivienda y ofrecerle diferentes opciones a su hijo. Trabaja en la Alcaldía de Villa del Carmen como guardia de seguridad, desde hace seis meses anteriormente trabajaba en la Zona Franca, se ha encontrado dificultades para la construcción de su casa y gracias al préstamo en Afodenic comprara materiales de construcción tales como: cemento, hierro, azulejo y otros materiales de construcción, siendo la iniciación de su proyecto.
texts.en:
Aldo O. lives in the Villa del Carman. His significant other works for a private business. He has a seven year old son. Aldo is a fighter who looks for the best for his family. He is a good father to his son. His plans are to make improvements to his house and to give his son different options. He has worked as a security guard in the Villa del Carmen region for six months. He previously worked in the Zona Franca. He has run into problems building his house. Thanks to the loan from Afodenic, he will buy construction materials like cement, iron, tile, and other materials as this is the beginning of the project.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr: Mme Ami T. est une coiffeuse ambulante dans son village Gamégblé. Née en 1965 et mère de quatre (04) enfants, elle mène cette activité depuis plusieurs années. Elle va de maison en maison et de village en village pour coiffer et teinter les femmes et les enfants. Cette activité lui permet de s’en sortir par les revenus qu’elle en tire. Elle sollicite un apport financier pour acheter les produits qu’elle utilise pour son travail et d’autres matériels de travail.
texts.en:
Ms. Ami T. is an itinerant hairdresser in her village, in Gamégblé. Born in 1965 and the mother of four children, she has been this business for several years. She goes from house to house, and from village to village, to cut or dye the hair of women and children. This business allows her to cope by the revenues she derives from it. Ami is requesting financial participation to buy the products she uses for her work and other work supplies or equipment.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hairdressing

loans.name: Lilliam

texts.es:
Lilliam A. Veliz es una señora de 62 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Cuatro Bocas de Upala, localizada en la Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura.

Doña Lilliam es viuda y tiene 5 hijos pero ya todos son mayores de edad por lo tanto no viven con ella pero si la ayudan  con diferentes gastos. Ella  se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente a la siembra de platano. Dice que el mercado para este producto es muy bueno. Comenta que gracias a este proyecto sus condiciones de vida han mejorado considerablemente y dice además que ha crecido como persona y ha adquirido mucho conocimiento.

En estos momentos doña Lilliam desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢650,000 (seiscientos cincuenta mil colones), para darle mantenimiento a su cosecha además comprar fertilizantes entre otros insumos. Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto poder incrementar la producción.
 
Doña Lilliam es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su sexto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Lilliam A. Veliz is a 62 year old women who lives in a small rural community in Costa Rica called Cuatro Bocas de Upala, located in the province of Alajuela. There, they have business activities such as storekeeping, double purpose cattle farming (meat and dairy), and agriculture.

Lilliam is a widow and has 5 children, but all of them are older so they do not live with her. However, they do help her with different expenses. She is involved in agriculture, specifically to the cultivation of bananas. She says that the market for this product is very good. She comments that thanks for this project her quality of life has improved considerably and she has also grown as a person and has acquired a great deal of knowledge.

Right now, Lilliam would like a loan of 650,000 CRC for the maintenance of her crops and also to purchase fertilizers, among other supplies. With this loan, she hopes to have a good harvest with a product with appropriate characteristics to have a good sales price to increase production.

Lilliam is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe, which consists of only women. It specializes in supporting women who are not professionals or the head of household. It is one of EDESA’s 100 partner organizations in Costa Rica. This will be Lilliam’s sixth loan and with it, she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level, in addition to actively participating in the loan organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies to maintain her banana plants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To sell grains

loans.name: Ruth Belia

texts.es:
Ruth Belia López G. es una señora de 36 años de edad, quien vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Cuatro Bocas de Upala, localizada en la Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura.

Desde hace ya varios años doña Ruth se dedica a la ganadería de doble propósito. Logra vender sus  productos a los vecinos de su comunidad quienes se muestran muy satisfechos con la calidad de los productos que ofrece. 

Doña Ruth  considera que gracias al progreso de este proyecto, ella y su familia han mejorado poco a poco sus condiciones de vida y ha logrado ser participe en el desarrollo de la comunidad, también comenta que desde que inicio con el negocio su autoestima ha mejorado mucho y ahora se siente muy capaz.

En estos momentos doña Ruth desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢650,000 (seiscientos cincuenta mil colones), para comprar 6 terneros machos y así  poder incrementar la producción. Ella sabe que contar con mayor número de vacas más es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo. Sin embargo, el deseo de ser una microempresaria exitosa y  sacar adelante a su familia mejorando las condiciones de vida, la motiva a esforzarse con gran esmero y dedicación.

Doña Ruth es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su cuarto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Ruth Belia López G. is a 36 year old woman who lives with her husband and 2 children. She lives in a small rural community in Costa Rica called Cuatro de Bocas de Upala, located in the province of Alajuela. There, they have business activities such as storekeeping, dual purpose cattle farming (meat and dairy), and agriculture.

Ruth has been involved in dual purpose cattle farming for several years now. She is able to sell her products to neighbors in her community, who are very satisfied with the quality of the products that she offers.

Ruth thinks that thanks to the progress of this project, she and her family have improved, little by little, their quality of life and that she has been able to be a participant in the development of the community. She also comments that since the beginning of the business, her self-esteem has increased greatly and now she feels very capable.

Right now, Ruth would like a loan of 650,000 CRC to purchase 6 male calves so that she can increase her production. She knows that having more cows is a bigger sacrifice and will require more work. However, her desire to have a successful small business and help her family get ahead and improve their living conditions motivates her to work with great care and dedication.

Ruth is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Bansuperafe, which consists of only women. It specializes in supporting women who are not professionals or the head of household. It is one of EDESA’s 100 partner organizations in Costa Rica. This will be Ruth’s fourth loan and with it, she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level, in addition to actively participating in the loan organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 6 calves

loans.name: La Alternativa 3 Group

texts.en:
Teresa A. (second from left) is a hardworking mother of three who sells used clothing to make a living. She sells what is called “ropa de paca," which is pre-made bundles of used clothing from the United States and other countries, organized into bags such as men’s clothing, women’s clothing and bedsheets. Juana travels to cities up to five hours away from her home in Samaná to purchase the clothing she sells to those in her neighborhood.

Teresa works from her home, where she lives with her husband and three children, ages 14, 10 and 4. Her customers drop by with orders and requests, and Teresa happily finds the necessary clothing when she purchases inventory. Currently on her eighth loan with Esperanza International, Teresa has proven to be a determined and responsible businesswoman. Recognizing the oversaturation of some other types of businesses, she decided to enter into clothing sales, where she has found sales to be brisk.

Many of Teresa’s profits go to feeding her children. With five people living at home, her husband’s salary as a boat driver is not sufficient to provide everything necessary for the family. Now, with Teresa augmenting the family’s income, all are comfortably fed and clothed.

In the future, Teresa dreams of having her own store from which she can sell her clothing and other goods. As well, when her children reach college age, she hopes to support their education at a local university.

Thank you for your Kiva loan to Teresa and the other members of her group!

loans.use: New packs of men's, women's and children's clothing

loans.name: Álvaro Santos

texts.es:
Alvaro Santos A. T. es un joven señor de 30 años, vecino de Los Tijos de Upala, localizado en la provincia de Alajuela. Es una comunidad rural  con una extensión relativamente grande, con topografía semi montañosa ubicada en Costa Rica, Centroamérica.  La comunidad se dedica especialmente a la agricultura de granos básicos, y en menor escala a la ganadería. Vive con sus padres su hermana y su sobrino.

Desde hace poco más de un año, don Alvaro se ha desarrollado como microempresario, tiene un pequeño terreno en el cual  se dedica a la siembra de camóte, un tubérculo de agradable sabor, rico en nutrientes, de procesamiento agroindustrial amplio y de gran demanda tanto en Costa Rica como en otros países. Dice que gracias a este proyecto ha aprendido mucho y también le ha dado oportunidad de desarrollarse personalmente y profesionalmente.

Actualmente don Alvaro está solicitando un préstamo de ¢600,000 (seiscientos mil colones), para ayudarse con  la preparación del suelo, compra de semillas, fertilizantes, entre otros insumos que sean necesarios para garantizar la siembra óptima del camote. 

Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto. Ya que desea realizar más proyectos en el futuro y también mejorar las condiciones de su familia.

Don Alvaro forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Los Tijos, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será  su primer préstamo y con el espera seguir creciendo como microempresario.
texts.en:
Alvaro Santos A. T. is a 30 year-old young man who lives in Los Tijos de Upala, a relatively large and mountainous rural community located in the province of Alajuela in Costa Rica, Central America. The community’s primary business is agriculture, growing basic grains, and its secondary business is cattle raising. Alvaro lives with his parents, his sister and his nephew.

A little over a year ago don Alvaro became a micro-entrepreneur. He has a small plot of land where he grows sweet potato, a flavorful tuber, rich in nutrients, widely grown and in great demand in Costa Rica as well as other countries. He has learned a lot from this project, which has given him the opportunity for personal and professional growth.

Don Alvaro is requesting a $1,025 (600,000 colones) loan to help with the soil preparation, purchase of seeds, fertilizers and other materials needed to guarantee an optimum sweet potato crop.

With this investment he hopes to get a good harvest with a high quality product that he can sell at a high price. He wants to start more projects in the future and improve his family’s quality of life.

Don Alvaro belongs to the Communal Credit Company of Los Tijos, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This is his first loan and he hopes to continue to grow as a micro-entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Rina Paguaga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials to harvest sweet potatoes

loans.name: Melania Isabel

texts.es:
Melania Isabel C. F. es una señora de 67 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada San José de Upala, localizada en la  Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y le che) y agricultura.
 
Doña Melania es viuda y tiene 3 hijos pero ya todos son mayores de edad por lo tanto no viven con ella pero si la ayudan  con diferentes gastos.  Doña Melania se dedica a la ganadería de leche, específicamente produce leche queso y otros  derivados;  los cuales vende tanto en su comunidad como en lugares vecinos, que según su criterio, hay un excelente mercado ya sea por medio de venta a intermediarios o al público directamente. 

Doña Melania  considera que gracias al progreso de este proyecto, sus condiciones de vida han mejorado mucho, también comenta que desde que inicio con el negocio su autoestima ha mejorado y ahora se siente muy capaz, dice que ha crecido mucho a nivel personal y profesional.

Doña Melania es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su sexto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Melania Isabel C. F. is 67. She lives in San José de Upala, a small rural community in Costa Rica, which is located in the Alajuela province. The community activities are business, dual purpose livestock (meat and milk), and agriculture. Mealnia is a widow with three children. The children are grown and do not live with her, but they do help with different expenses. Melania works in milk production. Specifically, she produces cheese made from milk and other milk derivatives. She sells to her community and to neighboring places. She feels there is an excellent market selling to intermediaries or directly to the public. Melania feels that thanks to the progress of this project, her living conditions have improved a lot. She also says that since the start of her business her self esteem has improved. She now feels very capable. She has grown a lot on a personal and professional level. Melania is a member of the Women’s Communal Credit Union La Esperanza. Its members are only women because they specialize in helping women who are not professionals and heads of households. It is one of the 100 organizations partnered with EDESA in Costa Rica. This is her sixth loan. She hopes to continue growing on and personal and economic level with the loan. She also plans to actively participate in the credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy three cows

loans.name: Ada

texts.es: Ada es una mujer muy trabajadora, tiene 48 años, vive con su esposo, Efraín, de 46 años; con sus hijos Joaquín de 16, Saúl de 15 y con su anciana madre de 79 años de edad en su casa propia. Desde hace 2 años se dedica a la elaboración de tejidos, los cuales vende a pedido, eligió este negocio porque es una actividad que puede realizar desde su hogar y al mismo tiempo dedicarle tiempo a su familia. A Ada le gusta mucho su trabajo, ya que puede obtener ingresos económicos extras, además que es un pasatiempo que tuvo desde que era joven. Adicionalmente, tiene otros negocios: el taxi que maneja su esposo diariamente y sus servicios como enfermera de una anciana los fines de semana, pues ella tiene estudios técnicos en enfermería. Ada está feliz porque puede generar ganancias para el bienestar de su familia, para un futuro cercano quiere comprar otro carro para ir formando una flota de taxis. Este es su tercer préstamo con un grupo solidario en MFP y le ha ido muy bien porque se unió con buenas y responsables compañeras. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar mayor cantidad de lana para realizar sus tejidos y también refaccionar el auto de su esposo.
texts.en:
Ada is a very hardworking woman. She is 48 years old. She lives with her husband, Efrain, who is 46 years old. She also lives with her sons 16 year old Joaquin, 15 year old Saul, and her elderly mother of 79 years in her own house. For 2 years she has woven fabric, which she sells at request. She chose this business because it is an activity which she can do from her home and at the same time take care of her family. Ada likes her work a lot as she can obtain an extra income and it is a past time she has had since she was young. In addition, she has other businesses: the taxi which her husband drives daily and her services as the nurse for an elderly woman on the weekends. She has taken technical studies in nursing. Ada is happy because she can generate earnings for the well-being of her family. In the near future they want to buy another car so that they can form a fleet of taxis. This is her third loan with a solidarity group in MFP (Microfinanzas PRISMA), and it has gone very well for her because she is with good and responsible partners. With the money she asks for, she wants to buy more yarn to create her cloth and also repair her husband’s car.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy yarn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To grow corn

loans.name: Carolina Patricia

texts.es:
Carolina Patricia T. R. es una señora de 33 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada La Esperanza localizada en San José de Upala, Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura. Doña Gloria vive con sus dos pequeños hijos.

 Hace poco tiempo doña Carolina se separó de su esposo y debido a que sus dos hijos están pequeños ella desea incursionar como microempresaria instalando una “soda” (un pequeño restaurante de comida criolla) en su propia casa. Dice que de esta forma podrá  ayudar con los gastos en su casa y que además no tendrá que salir de su casa y dejar a sus hijos. Ella comenta que en el pasado ha trabajado en diferentes restaurantes y “sodas” por lo cual tiene bastante experiencia; también  ha visto que es un muy buen negocio y que en su comunidad habría una muy buena aceptación. 

Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por ¢685,000 (seiscientos ochenta mil colones) específicamente comprará mercadería para vender, también una refrigeradora, una freidora, una licuadora entre otros utensilios que necesita para iniciar el negocio, y así podrá brindar un buen servicio a sus vecinos.

Doña Carolina es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Carolina is 33 years old and lives with her two small children in La Esperanza, a small rural community located in San Jose de Upala, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica. The region is dedicated to commerce, cattle-raising (for both meat and milk) and agriculture.

Recently, Carolina was separated from her husband and since her two children are small, she wished to start a micro-enterprise, installing a small restaurant serving local dishes in her own home. She says that in this manner she could help with household expenses and she would not have to go out of the house, leaving her children. In the past, she has worked in restaurants large and small, giving her sufficient experience. Also, she has seen that it is a very good business and that it would be well received in her community.

She needs to borrow $1,175 to buy merchandise to sell, plus a refrigerator, a deep fat fryer, and a blender, among other utensils necessary to start her business. This would enable her to provide good service to her neighbors.

Carolina belongs to La Esperanza Womens Community Credit organization, which helps women who are non-professionals or heads of households. It is one of 100 organizations associated with EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan. With it she hopes to continue her personal and economic development and to participate actively in the credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE OF UTENSILS AND MERCHANDISE

loans.name: Mariela

texts.es: Mariela tiene 34 años, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos en una casa alquilada, ella es una mujer que genera sus propios ingresos económicos. Desde hace 5 años tiene un restaurante, para este negocio se asoció con su madre y ambas ponen de su esmerada dedicación para atender a su clientela. Cada día preparan gran cantidad de platos variados, tanto para el desayuno, como para el almuerzo. Gracias a que le está yendo muy bien, con las ganancias puede afrontar los gastos familiares. Mariela escogió dedicarse a la venta de comida porque le agrada cocinar y con su buena sazón ha logrado conquistar la preferencia de sus clientes, quienes acuden a su establecimiento diariamente. Por ello, seguirá trabajando arduamente para hacer crecer su restaurante y contar en el futuro con un mejor local y todos los utensilios necesarios. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y está muy contenta de ser una de las integrantes de su grupo, pues se siente muy identificada con ellos. El dinero que está solicitando será utilizado para la compra de bebidas gaseosas y más platos de loza.
texts.en:
Mariela is 34 years old and lives with her husband and 4 children in a rented house. She is a woman who generates her own income. For the past 5 years she has operated a restaurant. She works with her mother and they are both dedicated to attending to their customers. Every day they prepare large quantities of food for breakfast and lunch. Because her business is doing well, Mariela is able to cover her household expenses. She chose to engage in the food business because she enjoys cooking and has a good time catering to her customers’ preferences.

Mariela will continue to work hard to expand her restaurant. In the future, she is looking to move her business to a better location and acquire all the necessary utensils. This is her third loan with MFP. She is excited to be part of her communal bank group because she identifies with each of the other members. The money she requested will be used to buy soft drinks and earthenware dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks & dishes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adwenpa Group

texts.en: Akosua is 40 years old. She is a married woman with five children. Two are currently in school.  She is very dedicated to her family and business. She is a food vendor and sells rice with gravy stew at the community school where she lives. She started her operation about 20 years ago in taking care of her home. She sells on a road side in the community where she lives. Her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables, and bags of rice to increase her efficiency to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to support her business growth and the children's education.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood etc.

loans.name: Candida

texts.es:
Candida C. C. es una señora de 68 años de edad, quien vive con su esposo,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada La Esperanza localizada en San José de Upala, Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y le che) y agricultura. 

Doña Candida se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente a la siembra de platano. Dice que el mercado para este producto es muy bueno. Comenta que gracias a este proyecto sus condiciones de vida han mejorado considerablemente y dice además que ha crecido como persona y ha adquirido mucho conocimiento, dice que se siente muy capaz y muy feliz de poder mantenerse activa.

En estos momentos doña Candida desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢685,000 (seiscientos ochenta y cinco mil colones), para darle mantenimiento a su cosecha además comprar fertilizantes, abonos entre otros insumos. Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto poder incrementar la producción. 

Doña Candida es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su cuarto préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Candida C. C. is 68 years old and lives with her husband in the small rural Costa Rican community of La Esperanza, located in San José of Upala, Alajuela Province. The main business activities for this area are cattle breeding (both meat and dairy) and agriculture. Doña Candida is a banana farmer. She says the demand for her product is very high. Thanks to her business, her living conditions have improved considerably and she has also grown as a person who has gained much knowledge through experience. Doña Candida is very happy that she can remain active. Doña Candida is currently requesting a microloan in the amount of 685,000 colones to pay for labor during the harvest season. She will also purchase fertilizers and other supplies. She hopes that this investment will result in a good harvest so that she can command a good price for her product. Doña Candida is a member of La Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres (the Women’s Communal Credit Union) in La Esperanza, which supports women entrepreneurs and heads of households. This institution is one of 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This is Doña Candida’s fourth loan and she hopes to continue growing personally and financially. She will also continue participating in the local credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies & pay for labor to harvest bananas

loans.name: Good Name Group

texts.en:
Adwoa is 37 years old. She is married and the mother of four children, and she has all her children in school. She sells food stuffs like rice, beans and plantains, etc., in the local market in her community. She has been selling for the past five years now, and she has lots of selling experience to win customers. She is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to strengthen her and the kids' education. She wants to use the loan to buy increased stock of rice, yams, beans, cooking oil and plantains to serve her customers. She would be grateful for that assistance. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Good Name’. She is the one sitting second from left in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors and/or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of cassava, plantains, maize, beans, gari, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.es: Mary es una mujer muy esforzada, tiene 29 años y vive con sus 2 hijos pequeños en su casa propia. Años atrás emprendió varios negocios que no generaron las ganancias esperadas, pese a estas caídas Mary insistió hasta llegar a donde se encuentra ahora, convertida en una muy buena costurera. Ella elabora diversos artículos, desde colchas para camas, hasta prendas deportivas; su taller textil lo implementó en su misma casa, donde trabaja cómodamente, sin descuidar la atención de sus dos pequeños hijos. Debido al buen acabado de sus trabajos está incrementando su lista de clientes, lo que la satisface aun más y le da ánimos para continuar. Mary planea para el futuro implementar un taller de costura más grande para producir en cantidades mayores. Esta es la tercera vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y la responsabilidad en sus pagos es reconocida por los demás integrantes de su banco comunal, donde se siente muy a gusto. El dinero que viene solicitando es para la compra una máquina de coser semi industrial, la cual facilitará de gran manera sus costuras.
texts.en:
Mary is a hardworking woman. She is 29 years old and lives with her 2 small children in her own home. Several years ago, she started a few businesses that did not generate the profits she had expected. Despite these obstacles, Mary developed into a very good seamstress. She produces all kinds of items, everything from bedspreads and quilts to sportswear. Her sewing workshop has been set been set up in her home, so that she can work comfortably and also look after her two young children. Due to the quality of her finished products, her list of clients continues to increase. This gives her great satisfaction and motivates her to continue working. Mary plans to open a larger workshop so that she can produce in larger quantities.

This is her third loan with MFP. The other members of her communal bank have taken note of her responsibility in making timely payments. Mary will use the money to buy a semi-industrial sewing machine, which will make her job easier.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina is 44 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children -- two sons and two daughters. All of her children are still in school. She works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Abuakwa in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Augustina is a beautician. She is a hair dresser by profession. She buys her logistics such as cream, lotion, shampoo and artificial hair from Kumasi. She also deals in textiles and jewels. She says she has trained a number of apprentices who have graduated and have established their own salon shops. Augustina has been in business for more than 15 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy hair dressing materials

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 28 years old. He is married and the father of one child. His child is still breastfeeding. Richie, as he is popularly called, is very hard working and dedicated to his business. For him to be in focus and stable, he has had to shun unnecessary things that were retarding both his family and business growth.

He deals in video and movie discs, a business he has done for three years now. He buys stock from Nigeria and spends almost a week or two before he returns to Ghana. He dreams of expanding his business by renting a store so that he can stock his shop to attract customers. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy video discs, African movies, foreign movies in bulk and used clothing, etc.

loans.name: Susana

texts.es: Susana tiene 55 años, es una mujer luchadora que vive con sus 2 hijos en la casa de un familiar. Hace más de 3 años decidió asociarse con una de sus hijas para emprender un negocio de venta de comida en una avenida céntrica y comercial de su localidad. Ambas se encargan de la preparación de los platos y de la atención a los comensales. Para ello, se esmeran mucho en cocinar variados guisos a gusto de sus clientes, así como de utilizar ingredientes de muy buena calidad. Gracias a este negocio, Susana ha podido incrementar sus ingresos económicos, por lo que está muy animada de continuar con su pequeño restaurante, mejorando cada día más la calidad y variedad de sus comidas. Esta es la segunda vez que tiene un crédito con MFP y está dispuesta a seguir realizando un trabajo solidario en su banco comunal, aportando para el bienestar común. El dinero que viene solicitando estará destinado a la compra de productos alimenticios de primera necesidad, al por mayor, para la preparación de sus comidas.
texts.en:
Susana is a fighter. She is 55 years old and lives with her 2 children in a relative’s house. For more than 3 years, she has been working with one of her daughters in their business of selling food on one of the central avenues and from a commercial eatery. They are both in charge of preparing the meals and attending to their customers. Thanks to her business, Susana has been able to increase her income and is encouraged to continue improving the quality and variety of her meals.

This is the second time she has requested a loan from MFP. She is prepared to continue working with her communal bank and supporting her fellow members for the wellbeing of the entire group. Susana will use her loan to purchase ingredients wholesale for the preparation of her meals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kwaku

texts.en:
Kwaku is 25 years old and he is married with one child who is currently in school. He is a dealer in mobile phones and accessories. He also provides repairs and service work for his customers. He says the sale of mobile phones has become a very lucrative business in Ghana because almost every Ghanaian desires to possess a mobile phone for easy and fast communication.

He buys his supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells to his customers at retail prices. He requests the loan to enable him to procure an increased stock of mobile phones and accessories. He hopes the loan would enable him to increase savings to expand his shop. With the loan he believes he can buy assorted phones so that his customers can make a choice from them. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To procure an increased stock of mobile phones and accessories.

loans.name: Ismenia

texts.es:
Ismenia M. G. es una señora de 61 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada La esperanza localizada en San José de Upala, Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura. Vive con uno de sus cuatro hijos.

Doña Ismenia se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente a la siembra de platano. Dice que el mercado para este producto es muy bueno. Comenta que gracias a este proyecto sus condiciones de vida han mejorado considerablemente y dice además que ha crecido como persona y ha adquirido mucho conocimiento, además ha aumentado su autoestima y su seguridad.

En estos momentos doña Ismenia desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢680,000 (seiscientos ochenta mil colones),para darle mantenimiento a su cosecha además comprar fertilizantes, abonos entre otros insumos. Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto poder incrementar la producción. 

Doña Ismenia es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su sexto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Ismenia M. G. is 61 years old and lives in the small rural Costa Rican community of La Esperanza, located in San José of Upala, Alajuela Province. The main business activities for this area are cattle breeding (both meat and dairy) and agriculture. She lives with one of her four children.

Doña Ismenia is a banana farmer. She says the demand for her product is very high. Thanks to her business, her living conditions have improved considerably and she has also grown as a person who has gained much knowledge through experience. It has also helped her increase her self-esteem and financial security.

Doña Ismenia is currently requesting a microloan in the amount of 680,000 colones to pay for labor during the harvest season. She will also purchase fertilizers and other supplies. She hopes that this investment will result in a good harvest so that she can command a good price for her product.

Doña Ismenia is a member of La Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres (the Women’s Communal Credit Union) in La Esperanza, which supports women entrepreneurs and heads of households. This institution is one of 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This is Doña Ismenia’s sixth loan and she hopes to continue growing personally and financially. She will also continue participating in the local credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies & pay for labor to harvest bananas

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 42 years old.  She is married and the mother of five kids. Currently, all her children are in school. She has been sewing for the past 21 years. She is a specialist in female and kids wear. Her skills and designs are of class.  She sews various kinds of attire that give her customers a new look, like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. She also sews night gowns and supplies them to hospitals and senior high school children. 

She wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She would be grateful for your assistance for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria T. M. es una señora de 52 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada La Esperanza localizada en San José de Upala, Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche) y agricultura. Doña Gloria vive con su esposo y dos de sus seis hijos.

Desde hace poco más de 5 años que doña Gloria inició un negocio de confección de ropa. Ella elabora diferentes tipos de prendas de vestir que luego vende en negocios de la comunidad y sus alrededores o incluso la llegan a buscarla a su casa. Su microempresa ha ayudado a que la condición de vida de su familia haya mejorado considerablemente.

En estos momentos doña Gloria desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢680,000 (seiscientos ochenta mil colones), para comprar una máquina  especial para coser y materiales como telas, hilos, etc. Con esta inversión espera poder incrementar su producción y mejorar la calidad de los  productos. Afirma que gracias a este préstamo podrá ofrecer más y mejores opciones para sus clientes actuales y potenciales.

Doña Gloria es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Gloria is 52 years old and lives in the small rural community of La Esperanza, in San Jose de Upala, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica. The local economic activities include commerce, livestock raising (for meat and milk), and agriculture. She lives with her husband and two of her six children.

It has been a little over 5 years since Gloria started her clothes making business. She makes different types of garments which she later sells in businesses locally and in the surrounding areas. People also come to her house to buy them. Her micro-enterprise has improved her family's condition of life considerably.

At present, Gloria wishes to obtain a loan of $1,175 to buy a special sewing machine and materials such as cloth, thread, etc. With this investment she hopes to increase production and improve the quality of her products. She assures us that with this loan she can offer more and better options to her existing and potential customers.

Gloria is a member of La Esperanza Womens Community Credit organization, which specializes in helping non-professional women and women who head households. It is one of 100 organizations belonging to EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be Gloria's second loan and with it, she hopes to continue her personal and economic growth, as well as participate actively in her community's credit organization.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING A SPECIAL SEWING MACHINE, CLOTH, THREAD, AND ACCESSORIES

loans.name: Mighty Forth Group

texts.en:
Ernestina is 48 years old. She is married and has given birth to six children who are all still in school. She is a trader in vehicle upholstery materials. Ernestina is the leader of a trust bank group called Mighty Forth Ladies. She is seated first from right. The members of this group are mostly traders and food vendors.

They buy their raw materials, wares or goods from Kumasi and sometimes from nearby communities, and sell at the market square in their community. The members have been in business for sometime and have amassed a great deal of experience in their businesses. It is in light of this that they are requesting for a loan to procure more goods to expand their business. The members of the group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan. It is their desire to give their children good education.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Jean Carla

texts.en:
Jean CarL. is 28 years old and has two children. She is a single parent. Jean CarL. and her sister have a decoration service. They use cloth and balloons to decorate rooms for parties and other events. They also rent out chairs.

Jean CarL. has been working with Kiva partner ManueL. Ramos for two years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Triunfadoras” (The Winners). She used her very first loan of 300 soles to purchase fabrics for her business. She plans to use this loan of 1500 soles to buy a motorcycle taxi. This vehicle will enable her to more easily transport the chairs and decorating materials that she uses in her business.

Jean CarL. has been using her loans from ManueL. Ramos to purchase more supplies for her business, which has been doing well. Jean CarL. is working hard in order to be able to purchase her own house.

loans.use: A motorcycle taxi to transport materials for a decoration service.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa is a 40-year-old woman. She is married and currently has four children. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment in their community. She is a trader in fresh fish sales. She takes stock of fresh fish from Kumasi, which is a nearby city. She sometimes buys them on credit and repays her suppliers in a week's time. She said she buys on credit because she does not have enough money to buy from the suppliers. She has increased her market share within a few months and lots of people buy from her. Currently, she sells the fish at the market center. She needs the loan to buy bulk supply of fresh fish from the market. She dreams to save more to rent and store, and also to buy a fridge to enable her buy more fish. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish in bulk to sell

loans.name: Julia Catalina

texts.es:
Julia Catalina H. T. es una señora de 37 años de edad quien vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos en una comunidad llamada El Saíno de Pital localizada en la provincia de Alajuela; cuyas principales actividades productivas son la ganadería y la agricultura, donde destaca el cultivo de la piña; siendo estas comercializadas principalmente en los mercados internacionales.  Por esta razón, el desarrollo de la comunidad ha venido creciendo en los últimos años generando una mayor demanda de productos y servicios, lo que ayuda a mitigar el efecto de inmigración.

Doña Julia tiene un salón de belleza en su casa dice que  así  ayuda a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y de sus hijos; pero ahora para ampliar su fuente de ingresos desea incursionar como vendedora de productos naturales, dice que iniciará vendiendo en su salón de belleza y casa por casa en su comunidad.

Por lo cual, doña Julia desea obtener un préstamo por ¢585,000 (quinientos ochenta y cinco mil colones) para comprar la mercadería y productos necesarios para iniciar con su nuevo proyecto. Dice estar muy entusiasmada por iniciar y espera que poco a poco su negocio crezca en calidad y cantidad.

Doña Julia es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Luz del Futuro Saino, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Julia Catalina H. T. is 37. She lives with her husband and their three children in a community called El Saíno e Pital, which is located in the Alajuela province. The principal productive activities there are livestock and agriculture. Growing pineapple stands out because it is primarily sold in the international markets. For this reason, the development of the community has been growing in the last few years. This generates a larger demand for products and services, which helps mitigate the effect of immigration. Julia has a beauty salon in her house. This way she helps her husband with the household expenses and their children’s expenses. Now, in order to increase her source of income she wishes to sell natural products. She will start selling in her beauty salon. She will also sell door to door in her community. To do that, Julia wishes to get a loan for ¢585,000 (five hundred eighty five thousand colones) to buy merchandise and the products necessary to start her new project. She is very enthusiastic about starting. Little by little her business will grow in quality and quantity. Julia is a member of the Women’s Communal Credit Union Luz del Futuro Saino, which is one of the 100 partner organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her second loan. She hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level. Thanks to this type of organization and their methods of facilitating loans, she can spend more time on productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Maribel Zonia

texts.en:
Maribel is 28 years old and is married with one child. She works together with her mother buying and selling regional farm products such as chickens, plantains, grains and beans. Maribel’s husband is a chef. Maribel and her family live in the city of Pucallpa.

Maribel has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for three years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Dalinas II.” She used her very first loan of 300 soles to invest in bakery products. With this loan of 2500 soles, Maribel will purchase farm products such as hens, plantains and beans. Since she first began receiving loans from Manuela Ramos, Maribel has worked with her mother purchasing and selling such farm products in Pucallpa’s port. (Pucallpa is located on the Ucayali, the wide brown river that flows past the city and eventually joins the Amazon to the north. Many small agricultural communities line the banks of the Ucayali.) Maribel is pleased to have her own business because it has enabled her to increase the earnings of her household and to support her husband and son. Maribel’s goal is to build a home for her family and to have a small home-based grocery shop.

loans.use: Hens, plantains and beans for sale.

loans.name: Winifred

texts.en: Winifred is 36 and her children are still in school. She works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Abuakwa in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Winifred is a trader. She runs a provisions store. She buys her goods such as sugar, candies, milk, bread, soap, etc., from Kumasi. Her store is located by the roadside in her community. Winifred has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Delina

texts.en:
Delina is 24 years old and has two young children. She is a single parent. She has a business selling cooked foods from her home in the evenings.

Delina has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for two years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Dalinas II”. She invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in candies for sale.

Since she began receiving loans from Manuela Ramos, Delina has worked independently. She has expanded her business ventures quite a bit since her first loan. Delina plans to invest this loan of 1,000 soles in her little restaurant business: she will purchase basic food items such as sugar, oil and rice.

As a single parent Delina must work very hard to support her two children. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for making it easy for her to get a loan. Delina’s goal is to eventually have a large, well-stocked general store. She also wants to ensure that her children get a good education.

loans.use: To purchase basic food items for her restaurant

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua is 38 years old and is married with four children. She has two boys and two girls who are currently in school.

Akua is a trader who deals with assorted products like cooking utensils and plastic bowls, lunch boxes, etc. In addition, she has also attached the sale of used-clothing to her existing business and, since then, she has recorded lots of progress. 

Akua mostly sells through hawking: that is, house to house selling. She has been trading for seven years now. She has attracted lots of customers who purchase from her when she mounts a stand to trade. She treks to Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods.

Recently, Akua has been facing challenges in her business as a result of inadequate funds to buy stock. She requests a loan to buy more supplies of the products she sells, like cooking utensils, used clothing, etc., which are frequently demanded by her numerous customers.

With the loan Akua believes she will be more resourced to make lots of profits which she could use to rent a store to reduce the frequent walking on the street to sell. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To increase her stock of inventory like cooking utensils and used-clothing

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha dedicates herself to a variety of different business ventures. She and her husband have a spare parts shop for motorbikes and motorcycle taxis in the city of Pucallpa. Martha also has a shop in the distant town of Contamana. Finally, she sells shoes. She plans to use this loan of 2500 soles to buy Brazilian shoes for sale. Martha’s shoe sales business has been doing very well.  

Martha is 41 years old and married with three children. Martha has been working with Kiva's partner, Manuela Ramos, for about four years and belongs to the communal bank “Las Colinas” (The Hills). With the help of her loans, Martha has been able to get ahead in her own business and support the family’s spare parts shop. Martha’s goals are to eventually have her own shoe store and to help her children get a good education.

loans.use: To buy shoes to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a food vendor. She prepares and sells kenkey, a local dish made from corn dough served hot with peppers and fried fish. She buys her ingredients from Kumasi and nearby communities. She sells on a tabletop on the street.

Joyce is 39 years old, married and has three children: one son and two daughters. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Abuakwa in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Joyce works very hard to help her husband provide for the family. She has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to buy maize in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena sells smoked fish. She started her fish sales eight years ago at the community market where she lives. She buys fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish and, because of that, many customers buy from her stand. She buys fish from the fish mongers when the demand is high. She has a large customer base as a result of her moderate prices and her good customer service.

Abena is 37 years old, a divorcee and the mother of three boys. Currently, all are in school. She requests this loan to increase her stock of fish. She dreams of giving her children quality education through the proceeds of her business, and she would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more smoked and dried fish

loans.name: Mayra

texts.en:
Mayra and her husband run a small welding and metalwork shop. She is 43 years old, married with three children. She used her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) to purchase materials for her metalwork shop. Mayra will use this loan of 3000 soles to buy iron sheets and to fix up part of the shop.

Mayra has been working with Kiva's partner, Manuela Ramos, for five years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Triunfadoras” (The Winners). She is pleased to be able to support her family’s business and contribute to her household’s income with the help of loans from Manuela Ramos. She is grateful for the organization’s confidence in her and in her business venture. Mayra’s goals are to expand the metalwork shop and to finish building a home for her family.

loans.use: To buy iron sheets and to repair a welding/metalwork shop

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy, age 36, sells garment cloth, shoes, slippers and lace materials at the community market center. Lace material is very useful for room and office decorations. She treks to Kumasi to buy her stock of goods. She started her business 10 years ago.

Mercy is married and the mother of four children. Currently, all her children attend school in the community where they live. Mercy works very hard to look after herself and her business. Her inventory is low because of inadequate funds. For this reason, she requests loan support to help make her business progress. She believes this loan will enable her to grow her business to the expected level.

loans.use: To purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk

loans.name: Enma

texts.en:
Enma has a business selling used clothing in the small towns near the city of Pucallpa where she lives. She is 52 years old and married with six children, all of whom are independent adults. Enma’s husband works as a driver. Enma has been engaged in the business of selling used clothing for many years. She sometimes also sells local fruits and vegetables when they are in season.

Enma has been working with Kiva's partner, Manuela Ramos, for four years and she is a member of the communal bank “San Fernando II”. She invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in vegetables for sale. Enma plans to invest this loan of 1300 soles in purchasing used clothing for sale. Enma would like to have her own clothing shop one day. In this way, she would not have to travel around to visit her customers – they would come to her. She also wants to begin selling fruits from other regions of Peru, particularly the coastal region.

loans.use: To buy used clothing for sale

loans.name: Emélido

texts.es:
Emélido O. Espinoza es un señor de 70 años de edad, quien vive con su esposa y su sobrino,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Las Delicias de Upala, localizada en la Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y leche), siembra de granos básicos: arroz, frijoles, maíz entre otros.

Desde hace ya varios años don Emélido se dedica a la ganadería de doble propósito. Logra vender sus  productos a los vecinos de su comunidad quienes se muestran muy satisfechos con la calidad de los productos que ofrece. En su caso en particular, la demanda es mayor de lo que puede ofrecer actualmente. 
Don Emélido considera que gracias al progreso de este proyecto, él y su familia han mejorado poco a poco sus condiciones de vida y ha logrado ser actores en el desarrollo de la comunidad, la cual se ve frecuentemente azotada por las inclemencias del tiempo y el desempleo.

Actualmente don Emélido desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢685,000 (seiscientos ochenta y cinco mil colones), para comprar tres vacas y así  poder incrementar la producción. El sabe que contar con mayor número de vacas más es un mayor sacrificio y demandará más trabajo. Sin embargo, el deseo de ser un microempresario exitoso y sacar adelante a su familia mejorando las condiciones de vida, lo motiva a esforzarse con gran esmero. 

Don Emélido es socio de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Datraban, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su segundo préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
